programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Closer Than Friends or Family? — Turning to AI for Companionship
programme.desc: The struggles of everyday life are driving more and more people to use AI chatbots to fill the void in their hearts. Attracted by the sense of support and the constant availability, some have even 'married' AI characters, or recreated deceased partners to fill the feelings of loss. Meanwhile in the US, there have been cases where bereaved families have sued AI companies, claiming that the bots caused loved ones to take their own lives. We look into the way people use AI, along with some precautions it might be wise to take. Guest: Satoh Ichiro (Professor, National Institute of Informatics)

programme.title: Century Signboards
programme.desc: Nori tsukudani, a popular topping in rice-loving Japan. Made with local nori from Tokyo Bay, it's a taste and tradition preserved for over 100 years.

programme.title: Nun's Cookbook
programme.desc: Seasonal recipes from the nuns of Otowasan Kannonji Temple: sesame-covered taro dumplings. Mash up some boiled taro and season with salt. Add some cheese, sprinkle with golden sesame seeds, and deep fry. This tasty and fragrant treat is perfect for autumn.

programme.title: Outside In: Lost in Academia
programme.desc: Norwegian sociolinguist Goran Vaage investigates Japanese laughter, or warai. He analyzes how comedy is ingrained into communication in everyday life and plays a vital role in social connection.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: A group of men use ladles to throw water over the buildings they pass at Hibuse Matsuri, the Fire Prevention Festival in Minamisoma, Fukushima Prefecture. Temperatures are often below freezing, and bonfires help to keep everyone warm. The event conveys a prayer for the safety of residents and buildings in the coming year. It originated around 1,200 years ago, when bandits set fire to a local shrine. Legend has it that a herd of deer brought waterlogged bamboo grass to put out the flames.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.desc: Shimauta is the soul music of Amami Oshima. Islanders have long used it to convey feelings in good times and bad. The history of the music and of the island itself is conveyed in time-lapse footage.

programme.title: Century Signboards
programme.desc: Edo Kiriko cut glass techniques, passed from artisan to artisan for over 100 years. More women who now pursue the craft create popular new designs.

programme.title: Nun's Cookbook
programme.desc: Seasonal recipes from the nuns of Otowasan Kannonji Temple: shiba-zuke pickles. Salt cucumbers and myoga, then mix with ume vinegar, red shiso and shiso juice. Store for 2 to 3 days and you have the perfect side dish to go with newly harvested rice.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: Gojinjo Taiko is a wild, powerful performance by masked drummers. It originated 400 years ago in the small coastal community of Nafune-machi in Ishikawa Prefecture. The story goes that, faced with an imminent attack by a powerful warlord, villagers used improvised masks to disguise themselves as oni (demons), and scared away the approaching forces. Gojinjo Taiko is performed not only at the summer matsuri (festival) but at local hotels in everyday life, as a form of community revitalization.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.sub-title: AMAMI: Tanaka Isson ― Amami's Legendary Painter
programme.desc: Tanaka Isson had a unique gift for portraying Amami Oshima's nature in art. A child prodigy, his career faltered until he moved to the island. Time-lapse footage hints at scenes that inspired him.

programme.title: Japan Railway Journal
programme.sub-title: Major Railways Helping Local Communities Grow
programme.desc: Private railway companies in Greater Tokyo are redeveloping areas along their lines. See how they are focusing on community growth over more traditional developer-led models.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: SHAKOTAN: Out of the Blue, Into the Flames
programme.desc: The Shakotan Peninsula in the west of Hokkaido is known for the vivid color of the sea, which has come to be known as "Shakotan Blue." This craggy land is the stage for a mysterious summer festival that has been passed down through numerous generations. From the sacred mikoshi (portable shrines) which are plunged into the sea to the colorful banners of the fishing boats and, finally, the fire-walking ceremony, this festival is a vibrant celebration of faith and life in a proud fishing community. Andrzej Rudz, a cinematographer and filmmaker from Poland, captures the stunning landscapes of Shakotan and the passion of its people with images that are both delicate and dynamic.

programme.title: Dig More Japan

programme.title: Dining with the Chef
programme.desc: Chef Saito teaches you how to cook two classic Japanese squid dishes: simmered squid and stir-fried squid. By following his techniques, you can easily enjoy simple yet flavorful squid dishes at home.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Giving Your All for a Moment's Action: Obikane Nobuyuki / Stunt Performer
programme.desc: World-class stuntman Obikane Nobuyuki won an Emmy Award for his work on the hit historical TV drama series "Shogun." He talks about his techniques for achieving realistic, thrilling action.

programme.title: Trails to Oishii Tokyo
programme.desc: In squid-loving Japan, spear squid is immensely popular. Tag along with fishers in Hokkaido and savor some regional cuisine, fresh sushi, and a special take on a beloved Italian-inspired inky dish. Reporter: Michael Keida

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: Airing Laundry at the Local Well
programme.desc: It's summer, and a group of women have gathered at the local well to do laundry in the shade. We learn about the different techniques and tools they used to wash and dry different types of kimonos.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Tourism Dream or Local Nightmare? Japan's 'Minpaku' Private Lodging Struggles
programme.desc: Demand for private lodgings known as minpaku is on the rise, with approximately 36,000 across Japan at present. A series of problems with trash and noise have led to moves by local governments to tighten regulations. While unexpected changes are underway, exploration is also ongoing to utilize private lodgings that are rooted in the local community. What should the future hold for private lodgings? We consider the current situation as they stand at a crossroads. Guest: Terakawa Seiji (Associate Professor, Kindai University)

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: Dining Alone at a Shinbashi Yakiniku Restaurant
programme.desc: A yakiniku grilled meat restaurant in Tokyo's busy Shinbashi district is tailored to solo diners. Why do these customers prefer to eat alone? For three days, we got down to the meat of the matter.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Closer Than Friends or Family? — Turning to AI for Companionship
programme.desc: The struggles of everyday life are driving more and more people to use AI chatbots to fill the void in their hearts. Attracted by the sense of support and the constant availability, some have even 'married' AI characters, or recreated deceased partners to fill the feelings of loss. Meanwhile in the US, there have been cases where bereaved families have sued AI companies, claiming that the bots caused loved ones to take their own lives. We look into the way people use AI, along with some precautions it might be wise to take. Guest: Satoh Ichiro (Professor, National Institute of Informatics)

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.sub-title: Sea of Okhotsk: Blessings of the Drift Ice
programme.desc: The Sea of Okhotsk lines the coast of Hokkaido Prefecture, the northernmost main island of Japan. Once again, the season of drift ice has arrived. The ice has traveled 1,000 kilometers from the northern seas to get here. Local temperatures in winter drop to 20 degrees Celsius below zero. Phytoplankton thrive within the drift ice, attracting a variety of creatures in search of sources of life. In this episode, we take a look at stories of people living with drift ice on the coast of the Sea of Okhotsk.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: The waxing and waning moon. Throughout Japan's history, it has been loved, cherished and given many special names. Moon-viewing events are held across the country at the time of the beautiful harvest moon, which occurs during the eighth month of the traditional calendar. And the moon's gravitational pull has long been important in agriculture and fishing. We introduce Japan's aesthetic appreciation of the moon and look at some new technology being developed for use on the lunar surface itself.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: A group of men use ladles to throw water over the buildings they pass at Hibuse Matsuri, the Fire Prevention Festival in Minamisoma, Fukushima Prefecture. Temperatures are often below freezing, and bonfires help to keep everyone warm. The event conveys a prayer for the safety of residents and buildings in the coming year. It originated around 1,200 years ago, when bandits set fire to a local shrine. Legend has it that a herd of deer brought waterlogged bamboo grass to put out the flames.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: Many Japanese kitchens are now hyper-modern, but two or three centuries ago, most were basic spaces with dirt floors. One turning point came after the Second World War. Large apartment complexes built to address a housing shortage needed to be compact. For the first time, cooking and eating spaces were combined into one carefully designed "dining kitchen." Since then, kitchens have improved in both comfort and convenience. We introduce the ongoing evolution of the Japanese kitchen.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.sub-title: Ehime: Cats in a Literary Town
programme.desc: Matsuyama City was once home to author Natsume Soseki. Two cats living there show us a beautiful garden and other historical scenery. At a temple, a cat gets breakfast from a monk and naps in a tree.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Satoyama Living: Country Customs Sustaining the Ancient Capital
programme.desc: The Satoyama style of living in harmony with nature, and the customs that influenced life in the ancient capital, survive in the mountains north of central Kyoto. Miyama is famous for its thatching tradition, and local artisans use age-old methods to re-thatch Kyoto's temples and shrines. An old inn in the town of Hanase continues to serve the local specialty, Tsumikusa (foraged wild foods) cuisine. Discover the local customs that keep Kyoto's culture alive.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.desc: This time: relaying messages. Dong Quoc Dung works for a sports equipment manufacturer. He was transferred to the Japanese headquarters of his Vietnamese company in 2018. He designs fishing reels. From meetings to design checks, he uses only Japanese. One day it is hoped he will return to Vietnam and use his Japanese skill to communicate with HQ in Japan. By role-playing and receiving guidance from experts, he'll learn how to take messages accurately. Today's kanji is "okuru." And in "After 5!," we visit a super Sento.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: At Yoshimura Mayu's atelier anyone can come in and make clothes. The materials are discards from industry and major brands. And working together leads to great ideas they couldn't come up with alone.

programme.title: Somewhere Street
programme.desc: Bari is a port town located at the heel of the Italian peninsula. An important hub of commerce since the time of ancient Rome, it's known for welcoming people of diverse cultures from Asia and Africa.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: CYCLE AROUND JAPAN Highlights
programme.desc: A ride through Hokkaido in early summer. We meet an artisan teaching handicrafts of the indigenous Ainu to the next generation, and a legendary trainer of an unusual horse race.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends
programme.desc: It is Rockie's birthday, but she has a brawl with her parents and runs off from home. Her grandmother comes running after her to learn what is bothering her. Educational theme: The preciousness of life.

programme.title: Texico
programme.desc: Learn the principles of programming without even touching a computer in this new-style education program. Unique animated characters assist in the fun and lucid introduction of 5 core programming processes: analysis, combination, generalization, abstraction and simulation.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: J-MELO
programme.desc: Experience the cutting edge of Japanese entertainment as we turn the spotlight on virtual artists. This week, a female duo with over 600 million video views: HIMEHINA. On Demand until April 8, 2026

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: This program is an animation series about a Japanese dog, Charo. He meets and is helped by many mythical creatures of Northern Japan as he searches for eight star talismans.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: Many Japanese kitchens are now hyper-modern, but two or three centuries ago, most were basic spaces with dirt floors. One turning point came after the Second World War. Large apartment complexes built to address a housing shortage needed to be compact. For the first time, cooking and eating spaces were combined into one carefully designed "dining kitchen." Since then, kitchens have improved in both comfort and convenience. We introduce the ongoing evolution of the Japanese kitchen.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.sub-title: Ehime: Cats in a Literary Town
programme.desc: Matsuyama City was once home to author Natsume Soseki. Two cats living there show us a beautiful garden and other historical scenery. At a temple, a cat gets breakfast from a monk and naps in a tree.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Hit the Road
programme.desc: Our journey takes us through Hokkaido's winter southwest to Hakodate, where history meets one of Japan's most breathtaking night views.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Satoyama Living: Country Customs Sustaining the Ancient Capital
programme.desc: The Satoyama style of living in harmony with nature, and the customs that influenced life in the ancient capital, survive in the mountains north of central Kyoto. Miyama is famous for its thatching tradition, and local artisans use age-old methods to re-thatch Kyoto's temples and shrines. An old inn in the town of Hanase continues to serve the local specialty, Tsumikusa (foraged wild foods) cuisine. Discover the local customs that keep Kyoto's culture alive.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.desc: This time: relaying messages. Dong Quoc Dung works for a sports equipment manufacturer. He was transferred to the Japanese headquarters of his Vietnamese company in 2018. He designs fishing reels. From meetings to design checks, he uses only Japanese. One day it is hoped he will return to Vietnam and use his Japanese skill to communicate with HQ in Japan. By role-playing and receiving guidance from experts, he'll learn how to take messages accurately. Today's kanji is "okuru." And in "After 5!," we visit a super Sento.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: At Yoshimura Mayu's atelier anyone can come in and make clothes. The materials are discards from industry and major brands. And working together leads to great ideas they couldn't come up with alone.

programme.title: The Truth Behind the "Bear Crisis"
programme.desc: Japan is experiencing the worst case of bear attacks on record. Together with experts, we investigate to reveal bears' changing relationship with humans‐and how we can live safely alongside them.

programme.title: GRAND SUMO Legends
programme.desc: Late Yokozuna Chiyonofuji overcame shoulder injuries and achieved immense success due to his rigorous training. We look back on his technique, dedication to family and strength through adversity.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Crafting the Ultimate Kitchen Knife: Kurosaki Yu / Blacksmith
programme.desc: Kurosaki Yu is a blacksmith specializing in Echizen cutlery, a 700-year-old Japanese craft. His knives are sought after by chefs in Japan and overseas. He talks about achieving ultimate sharpness.

programme.title: IMPACTS: Climates Change the World
programme.sub-title: Endangered Journey: The Decline of Japan's Chum Salmon
programme.desc: Japanese chum salmon migrate over 20,000 kilometers in their return journey across the North Pacific. Global warming has caused an alarming decline in returning salmon and requires urgent action.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: Centuries ago, Tokyo was known as EDO. More than a million people enjoyed life in this city, they live on in ukiyo-e woodblock prints. Take a deep dive into ukiyo-e and explore the soul of old Tokyo.

programme.title: Medical Frontiers
programme.sub-title: New Findings on Walking and Running
programme.desc: Interval Walking Training, developed in Japan, is attracting global attention. The latest scientific findings show that alternating between fast walking and slow walking promotes health.

programme.title: Gunmachan (Ep. 5)
programme.desc: Join Gunmachan and friends for playful adventures full of laughter and curiosity, and explore the charm of Gunma Prefecture's traditions, culture, and specialties.

programme.title: Japanology Plus

programme.title: Train Cruise

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: The waxing and waning moon. Throughout Japan's history, it has been loved, cherished and given many special names. Moon-viewing events are held across the country at the time of the beautiful harvest moon, which occurs during the eighth month of the traditional calendar. And the moon's gravitational pull has long been important in agriculture and fishing. We introduce Japan's aesthetic appreciation of the moon and look at some new technology being developed for use on the lunar surface itself.

programme.title: Time and Tide
programme.desc: Whether outnumbered or laying siege to a seemingly impenetrable fortress, master strategist Kuroda Kanbei used his wits to win on the battlefield.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.sub-title: The Manyoshu Edition / Episode II: Business
programme.desc: The Manyoshu is the oldest extant anthology of Japanese poetry. Through poems presented in manga and a modern setting, we glimpse sentiments from centuries ago. The topic this time is business.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: A group of men use ladles to throw water over the buildings they pass at Hibuse Matsuri, the Fire Prevention Festival in Minamisoma, Fukushima Prefecture. Temperatures are often below freezing, and bonfires help to keep everyone warm. The event conveys a prayer for the safety of residents and buildings in the coming year. It originated around 1,200 years ago, when bandits set fire to a local shrine. Legend has it that a herd of deer brought waterlogged bamboo grass to put out the flames.

programme.title: Ethical Every Day
programme.sub-title: The Hidden Potential of Eco-friendly Materials
programme.desc: Eco-friendly materials have the potential to reduce CO2 emissions. We look at a major brand using renewable plant fibers for new threads, useful items made from fruit and vegetable waste, and more!

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.desc: From protecting valuable ceramics to reinforcing World Heritage structures, we'll see how the latest disaster preparedness technology is safeguarding Japan's irreplaceable cultural properties.
